title: Authors and Citation
text: Coia V (2024). famish: Refine family distributions match observations. R package version 0.1.0.9000.
code: @Manual{,   title = {famish: Refine a family of distributions to match observations},   author = {Vincenzo Coia},   year = {2024},   note = {R package version 0.1.0.9000}, }

what: Refine a family of distributions to match observations
title: Refine a family of distributions to match observations
text: goal famish refine family distributions meet specific requirements, often derived real data. includes parameter estimation methods like maximum likelihood, well partial constraints mean matching. name “famish” reflects process narrowing broad family distributions best fit needs.

title: Refine a family of distributions to match observations
text: can install development version famish GitHub :

title: Refine a family of distributions to match observations
text: Simple example: realistic example (development): Experts judged probability failure (PoF) engineered structure 5%, 90% certain PoF falls 1% 10%. distribution fit PoF? Since PoF must 0 1, may start Beta family distributions. sure want expected value 5%, restrict family Beta distributions mean 5%: Finally narrow family distribution whose 5th 95th percentiles close 1% 10%, respectively: Together pipe:
code: library(famish) x <- stats::rnorm(30) fit_dst_norm(x) #> norm parametric dst #>  #>  name : #> [1] "norm" # fam <- dst_beta() # fam2 <- restrict(fam, ...) # resolve(fam2, ...) # dst_beta() |>  #   restrict(...) |> #   resolve(...)

what: Select a Distribution from Quantiles — dst_from_quantiles
title: Select a Distribution from Quantiles — dst_from_quantiles
text: Select distribution closely follows specified quantiles, terms maximum likelihood. useful list quantiles distribution, know parameters; , elicited quantiles expert judgement, want closest distribution.

title: Select a Distribution from Quantiles — dst_from_quantiles
code: dst_from_quantiles(quantiles, probs, data, family, n = 1000, start)

title: Select a Distribution from Quantiles — dst_from_quantiles
text: quantiles Vector quantiles. probs Vector non-exceedance probabilities corresponding quantiles. data Optional; data frame containing quantiles probabilities. supplied, `quantiles` `probs` can remain unquoted. family Name distribution fit. n Number data points use fitting. start Optional; named list starting parameters used fitting procedure.

title: Select a Distribution from Quantiles — dst_from_quantiles
text: probability distribution.

title: Select a Distribution from Quantiles — dst_from_quantiles
text: Parameters selected resulting largest likelihood creating censored dataset. Interval-censored data created two consecutive quantiles, left- right-censored data created smallest largest quantiles. total `n` censored observations created. `start`ing parameters specified, found fitting distribution quantiles data. `NA`s found, removed, along corresponding `probs` `quantile` entry.

title: Select a Distribution from Quantiles — dst_from_quantiles
code: library(distionary) d1 <- distionary::dst_gev(0, 1, 1) qf <- distionary::enframe_quantile(d1, at = c(0.1, 0.5, 0.65, 0.7, 0.8, 0.9),                                    arg_name = "prob")  ## Retrieve the GEV parameters matching <- dst_from_quantiles(quantile, prob, data = qf, family = "gev") distionary::parameters(matching) #> $location #> [1] -0.003928957 #>  #> $scale #> [1] 0.9936664 #>  #> $shape #> [1] 0.9984534 #>   ## Find the closest Log Pearson Type III distribution having these quantiles closest_lp3 <- dst_from_quantiles(   quantile, prob, data = qf, family = "pearson3" ) distionary::parameters(closest_lp3) #> $mean #> [1] 2.308462 #>  #> $sd #> [1] 4.743186 #>  #> $skew #> [1] 3.286967 #>   ## Elicit quantiles from expert judgement, and fit a Pearson Type III judgement <- data.frame(prob = c(0.25, 0.5, 0.75),                         quantile = c(40, 100, 200)) fit <- dst_from_quantiles(quantile, prob, data = judgement,                           family = "pearson3") distionary::parameters(fit) #> $mean #> [1] 142.7415 #>  #> $sd #> [1] 143.3811 #>  #> $skew #> [1] 1.929726 #>
